g.text: . With horizontal resolution of 2° latitude by 2.5° longitude and 40 vertical
layers, the atmospheric model extends through the mesosphere (model top of 0.1 hPa). The latter is coupled
, which has horizontal resolution of 1° latitude by 1.25° longitude and 32 vertical
layers. As well, HadGEM2-ES is a coupled Earth System Model, used by the Met Office Hadley Centre for the
Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 centennial simulations. It comprises an atmospheric GCM at
1.875° (lon) horizontal and 40 km vertical resolutions, and an ocean GCM with a 1° horizontal reso-
3° at the equator) and 40 vertical layers.
The delta-change technique perturbs the locally generated weather record with additive or multiplicative
coefficients, based on the mean change from baseline to future frames extracted from the climate models. This
approach circumvents the inherent limitations of a conventional delta-change approach that barely applies mean
additive or multiplicative adjustments directly to reference baseline
Climate change impact on estimated rice yields.
As climate-change impact measure, we considered the
projected to current rice yields estimated with the crop model WARM
rice-growing seasons in 20 years of weather data in both hemispheres). We applied the impact study on rice yield
at multiple sites using weather series obtained from different GCM
we could in particular estimate the relative weight of the uncertainties in the output with respect to the WG used.
Robust rank analysis of variance (ANOVA) tests
ducted using climatic and agro-climatic indices coming from downscaled outputs under conditions identified
by four factors. A split-plot design with
further extended to accommodate a fourth factor - weather generator (CLIMAK, LARS-WG, WeaGETS) -
through additional subdivision of each sub-sub-plot into sub-sub-subplot. For the ANOVA, years were used as
replication within each 20-year period. Here, the ANOVA tests were based on Rfit code
metric ANOVA adopted does not require the assumptions of homogeneity of variance between the groups and
the normality of residuals, a balanced design (the same amount of index values for each level of each factor) is
required to detect the differences between the groups. Flaws in the generation process ended in having a limited
set of series fulfilling the requirements (Fig.
and Supplementary Table 2). The reason is that the failure in one
WG combination drives to failure for the whole location when trying to compare future pro-
jections. When one site encountered failures only in future scenarios, it was used in the analysis performed on
). Vice versa, when errors occurred only in the baseline generation (Fig.
included in the analysis of future scenarios. In this way, all the ANOVA tests were performed according to a bal-
anced design, depending on the occurrence of failures during weather generation.
The datasets generated during and/or analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding
ECMWF policies prompt not to reproduce, distribute, license, transfer, assign, sell, disclose or otherwise for-
ward the Archive Products. By the way, weather data may come from whatever source with no difference in the
CLIMAK official page for further information and availability: http://semola.uniud.it/index.php?id

Royal Society of London A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences
6. Knutti, R., Furrer, R., Tebaldi, C., Cermak, J. & Meehl, G. A. Challenges in combining projections from multiple climate models.

report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC, 2014).

Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and

10. Huang, W. K., Stein, M. L., McInerney, D. J., Sun, S. & Moyer, E. J. Estimating changes in temperature extremes from millennial-scale
climate simulations using generalized extreme value (GEV) distributions.
Advances in Statistical Climatology Meteorology and
. Quantifying Changes in Future Intensity-Duration-Frequency Curves Using Multimodel Ensemble Simulations.
12. Hansen, J. W. & Ines, A. V. Stochastic disaggregation of monthly rainfall data for crop simulation studies.
